conclusion: The voltmeter reading is U_{0} when the angular velocity of OO' is \omega_{0}. The magnetic induction intensity is B_{0}.
The magnetic induction intensity is changed to nB_{0}. The voltmeter reading is to be mU_{0}.
The voltage reading of the voltmeter is directly proportional to the angular velocity of the shaft.

premise: The voltage reading of the voltmeter is directly proportional to the angular velocity of the shaft.
conclusion: Mathematically, this relationship can be expressed as U = \omega \cdot B where U is the voltage reading, \omega is the angular velocity, and B is the magnetic induction intensity.

We need to find the new angular velocity (\omega') such that the voltmeter reading becomes mU_{0}. Using the relationship U = \omega \cdot B, we can express the new angular velocity as \omega' = \frac{mU_{0}}{B}.

premise: U_{0} = \omega_{0} \cdot B_{0} and mU_{0} = m \cdot \omega_{0} \cdot B_{0}
The angular velocity of the rotation of OO' should become m \omega_{0} to achieve a voltmeter reading of mU_{0} when the magnetic induction intensity is changed to nB_{0}.
conclusion: The angular velocity of the rotation of OO' should be changed to \frac{m}{n}\omega_{0}.
